body.p:
Your letter of Monday satisfied me that you were
better; but the one you wrote on Wednesday completely satisfied
me, that you were recovering, and your spirits were good,
better even than usual. I almost flatter myself, that
my book contributed something to that result, if so, I really
must thinke it one of the most desirable results it
could have. I am much indebted to Mr. Cohen for his
considerate kindness in handing the paper to you, and it proves that
his friendliness towards me has not abated. Have the goodness to
express to him my sense of obligation for his firm support he
always extended to me in my ? enterprizes, and assure
him, that I am rejoiced, that a judicious man like himself
has not found reason to abate of his support, which he once
extended. There is so little to cheer me on, that such appro-
bation is doubly? valuable._ I would write to him myself, but
I have heard of no opportunity, and it is almost useless to
write by mail, when I have you, to speak for me.__The whole
of the contents of your letter are noted, and I return my
sincere thanks for the expression of your good will, and I
trust, that the result may not disappoint us.

I send you, to the care of David Judah, thirty copies of the
Discourses; they are sent in a box which my printers
have d'spatched to Mr. Herman Bookseller, in Market near
North Street. I expect he will charge 50¢ freight. Mr. Judah

may inquire for them by Wednesday or Thursday, when I expect, they will
have been received. When I mentioned in one of my letters that the
Editor of the Patriot notice it, I neglected to mention the manner
in which it might be done. Mr. Judah, who in all likelihood knows
Mr. Minroe, might take a copy to him as a present, editors other_
wise cannot speak, and request him to read it. It is highly probable
that he will notice it. You might have half a dozen placed at some
bookstore; they will charge a commission for selling, but that need
not be minded, if a few could thereby be made to circulate among
. the Goyim, particularly the ministers, who may not altogether relish
to find sounder doctrines among us, than they give us credit for.__
However you may do as you please.__Perhaps it might also be advi-
sable to have a copy sent to Mr. J. H. Phesants to Richmond;
but you & Mr. Judah must judge of that between yourselves,
I myself do not like to write to Editors, it looks, and would
in fact be, like fishing for compliments;—but if friends do it, it is
quite another thing._

I was sorry to hear last week, that Mr. Jude was dead. I heard
it from Rebecca Ansel._

It grieves me to hear so much blame attached to Jews
for the recent failures. Herman, you think, is now called a Jew!
he is married to a Goya, his children are Goyim, his partners
are Goyim! It is also bad; so much for liberality! So much more necessi-
ty for diffusing a knowledge of our religion abroad, & show, that rogue_
ry is not belonging to our creed. Another house, deeply connected with
New Orleans has failed here, Jackson, Riddle & Co., they are no Jews;
the only Jews that are gone here are Isaac Phillips & Joseph L? Moss;
particulars have not come to my knowledge I do not like to ask.

News of any other sort are very rare here.__There was a fireman's parade
today & I did not see it all._ Our Synagogue since its repairs is
much improved in appearance; painting are other alterations has
also improved the sound.__You have I can imagine here large a number
of people inquire about you; everyone seemed concerned to hear of
your illness & your recovery too delightell?:

Give my best regards to Aunt R. Mrs DePass, Messrs
Judah & Block & the young ladies.

Command my services whenever you desire them
and remember occasionally

Misses Rachel & Simha Peixotto & B. ? desire
their love to you & Aunt Rehine.___

The desire also to be remembered to Abby & D. Judah,
and the rest of the family, especially Mr. DeP. From Mrss S C.P.

Tell Mr Cohen that I am rejoiced at his mother's recovery,
and that it may be an earnest of further prospering? to their
family.—
